Condition: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction
Medications: Cilostazol, Aspirin, Diclofenac, Diflunisal, Etodolac, Fenoprofen, Ibuprofen, Ketoprofen, Meclofenamate, Mefenamic Acid, Meloxicam, Nabumetone, Naproxen, Oxaprozin, Piroxicam, Sulindac, Tolmetin, Celecoxib
Rationale: Potential to promote fluid retention and/or exacerbate heart failure (NSAIDs and COX-2 inhibitors, nondihydropyridine CCBs, thiazolidinediones); potential to increase mortality in older adults with heart failure (cilostazol and dronedarone)

Condition: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
Medications: Cilostazol, Diltiazem, Verapamil, Aspirin, Diclofenac, Diflunisal, Etodolac, Fenoprofen, Ibuprofen, Ketoprofen, Meclofenamate, Mefenamic Acid, Meloxicam, Nabumetone, Naproxen, Oxaprozin, Piroxicam, Sulindac, Tolmetin, Celecoxib
Rationale: Potential to promote fluid retention and/or exacerbate heart failure (NSAIDs and COX-2 inhibitors, nondihydropyridine CCBs, thiazolidinediones); potential to increase mortality in older adults with heart failure (cilostazol and dronedarone)

Condition: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, asymptomatic
Rationale: Potential to promote fluid retention and/or exacerbate heart failure

Condition: Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, asymptomatic
Rationale: Potential to promote fluid retention and/or exacerbate heart failure

Medications: Donepezil, Rivastigmine, Galantamine, Tacrine, Doxazosin, Prazosin, Terazosin, Amitriptyline, Imipramine, Clomipramine, Trimipramine, Doxepin, Chlorpromazine, Thioridazine, Olanzapine
Rationale: AChEIs cause bradycardia and should be avoided in older adults whose syncope may be due to bradycardia. Nonselective peripheral alpha-1 blockers cause orthostatic blood pressure changes and should be avoided in older adults whose syncope may be due to orthostatic hypotension. Tertiary TCAs and the antipsychotics listed increase the risk of orthostatic hypotension or bradycardia

Medications: Disopyramide, Pyrilamine, Triprolidine,  Amitriptyline, Amoxapine, Clomipramine, Desipramine, Doxepin (>6 mg), Darifenacin, Imipramine, Fesoterodine, Nortriptyline, Flavoxate, Paroxetine, Oxybutynin, Protriptyline, Solifenacin, Trimipramine, Tolterodine, Trospium, Prochlorperazine, Promethazine, Benztropine, Trihexyphenidyl, Brompheniramine, Carbinoxamine, Chlorpromazine, Chlorpheniramine, Clozapine, Clemastine Loxapine, Cyproheptadine, Olanzapine, Dexbrompheniramine Perphenazine, Dexchlorpheniramine, Thioridazine, Dimenhydrinate, Trifluoperazine, Diphenhydramine (oral), Doxylamine, Hydroxyzine, Atropine (excludes ophthalmic), Meclizine, Belladonna alkaloids, Clidinium-chlordiazepoxide, Scopolamine (excludes ophthalmic), Dicyclomine, Homatropine (excludes ophthalmic), Hyoscyamine, Cyclobenzaprine, Methscopolamine, Orphenadrine, Propantheline, Alprazolam, Estazolam, Lorazepam, Oxazepam, Temazepam, Triazolam, Chlordiazepoxide, Clonazepam, Clorazepate, Diazepam, Flurazepam, Quazepam, Chlorpromazine, Droperidol, Fluphenazine, Haloperidol, Loxapine, Perphenazine, Pimozide, Prochlorperazine, Thioridazine, Thiothixene, Trifluoperazine, Aripiprazole, Asenapine, Clozapine, Iloperidone, Lurasidone, Olanzapine, Paliperidone, Quetiapine, Risperidone, Ziprasidone, Pimavanserin, Hydrocortisone, Cortisone, Betamethasone, Prednisone, Prenisolone, Triamcinolone, Methylprednisolone, Dexamethasone, Ethamethasoneb, Cimetidine, Famotidine, Nizatidine, Ranitidine, Meperidine, Eszopiclone, Zaleplon, Zolpidem
Rationale:
Avoid in older adults with or at high risk of delirium because of potential of inducing or worsening delirium.
Avoid antipsychotics for behavioral problems of dementia and/or delirium unless nonpharmacological options (eg, behavioral interventions) have failed or are not possible and the older adult is threatening substantial harm to self or others. Antipsychotics are associated with greater risk of cerebrovascular accident (stroke) and mortality in persons with dementia.

Medications: Disopyramide, Pyrilamine, Triprolidine,  Amitriptyline, Amoxapine, Clomipramine, Desipramine, Doxepin (>6 mg), Darifenacin, Imipramine, Fesoterodine, Nortriptyline, Flavoxate, Paroxetine, Oxybutynin, Protriptyline, Solifenacin, Trimipramine, Tolterodine, Trospium, Prochlorperazine, Promethazine, Benztropine, Trihexyphenidyl, Brompheniramine, Carbinoxamine, Chlorpromazine, Chlorpheniramine, Clozapine, Clemastine Loxapine, Cyproheptadine, Olanzapine, Dexbrompheniramine Perphenazine, Dexchlorpheniramine, Thioridazine, Dimenhydrinate, Trifluoperazine, Diphenhydramine (oral), Doxylamine, Hydroxyzine, Atropine (excludes ophthalmic), Meclizine, Belladonna alkaloids, Clidinium-chlordiazepoxide, Scopolamine (excludes ophthalmic), Dicyclomine, Homatropine (excludes ophthalmic), Hyoscyamine, Cyclobenzaprine, Methscopolamine, Orphenadrine, Propantheline, Alprazolam, Estazolam, Lorazepam, Oxazepam, Temazepam, Triazolam, Chlordiazepoxide, Clonazepam, Clorazepate, Diazepam, Flurazepam, Quazepam, Eszopiclone, Zaleplon, Zolpidem, Chlorpromazine, Droperidol, Fluphenazine, Haloperidol, Loxapine, Perphenazine, Pimozide, Prochlorperazine, Thioridazine, Thiothixene, Trifluoperazine, Aripiprazole, Asenapine, Clozapine, Iloperidone, Lurasidone, Olanzapine, Paliperidone, Quetiapine, Risperidone, Ziprasidone, Pimavanserin
Rationale:
Avoid because of adverse CNS effects
Avoid antipsychotics for behavioral problems of dementia and/or delirium unless nonpharmacological options (eg, behavioral interventions) have failed or are not possible and the older adult is threatening substantial harm to self or others. Antipsychotics are associated with greater risk of cerebrovascular accident (stroke) and mortality in persons with dementia.

Medications: Phenytoin, Valproic Acid, Phenobarbital,  Lamotrigine, Carbamazepine, Topiramate, Oxcarbazepine, Zonisamide, Gabapentin, Levetiracetam, Pregabalin, Clonazepam, Lacosamide, Rufinamide, Vigabatrin, Chlorpromazine, Droperidol, Fluphenazine, Haloperidol, Loxapine, Perphenazine, Pimozide, Prochlorperazine, Thioridazine, Thiothixene, Trifluoperazine, Aripiprazole, Asenapine, Clozapine, Iloperidone, Lurasidone, Olanzapine, Paliperidone, Quetiapine, Risperidone, Ziprasidone, Pimavanserin, Alprazolam, Estazolam, Lorazepam, Oxazepam, Temazepam, Triazolam, Chlordiazepoxide, Clonazepam, Clorazepate, Diazepam, Flurazepam, Quazepam, Eszopiclone, Zaleplon, Zolpidem, Amitriptyline, Amoxapine, Clomipramine, Desipramine, Doxepin, Imipramine, Nortriptyline, Paroxetine, Protriptyline, Trimipramine, Citalopram, Escitalopram, Fluoxetine, Paroxetine, Sertraline, Desvenlafaxine, Duloxetine, Levomilnacipran, Milnacipran, Venlafaxine, Opium, Heroin, Codeine, Oxycodone, Hydrocodone, Tramadol, Morphine, Hydromorphone, Fentanyl, Carfentanil
Rationale:
May cause ataxia, impaired psychomotor function, syncope, additional falls; shorteracting benzodiazepines are not safer than long-acting ones.
If one of the drugs must be used, consider reducing use of other CNS-active medications that increase risk of falls and fractures (ie, antiepileptics, opioid-receptor agonists, antipsychotics, antidepressants, nonbenzodiazepine and benzodiazepine receptor agonist hypnotics, other sedatives/hypnotics) and implement other strategies to reduce fall risk. Data for antidepressants are mixed but no compelling evidence that certain antidepressants confer less fall risk than others.

Medications: Metoclopramide, Prochlorperazine, Promethazine, Chlorpromazine, Droperidol, Fluphenazine, Haloperidol, Loxapine, Perphenazine, Pimozide, Prochlorperazine, Thioridazine, Thiothixene, Trifluoperazine, Aripiprazole, Asenapine, Iloperidone, Lurasidone, Olanzapine, Paliperidone, Risperidone, Ziprasidone
Rationale:
Dopamine-receptor antagonists with potential to worsen parkinsonian symptoms.
Exceptions: Pimavanserin and clozapine appear to be less likely to precipitate worsening of Parkinson disease. Quetiapine has only been studied in low-quality clinical trials with efficacy comparable to that of placebo in five trials and to that of clozapine in two others.

Condition: History of gastric or duodenal ulcers
Medications: Aspirin (>325 mg/day), Diclofenac, Diflunisal, Etodolac, Fenoprofen, Ibuprofen, Ketoprofen, Meclofenamate, Mefenamic acid, Meloxicam, Nabumetone, Naproxen, Oxaprozin, Piroxicam, Sulindac, Tolmetin
Recommendation: Avoid unless other alternatives are not effective and patient can take gastroprotective agent (i.e. proton-pump inhibitor or misoprostol)
Rationale: May exacerbate existing ulcers or cause new/additional ulcers

Condition: Chronic Kidney Disease (stage 4 or higher - creatinine clearance <30 mL/min)
Medications: Aspirin, Diclofenac, Diflunisal, Etodolac, Fenoprofen, Ibuprofen, Ketoprofen, Meclofenamate, Mefenamic acid, Meloxicam, Nabumetone, Naproxen, Oxaprozin, Piroxicam, Sulindac, Tolmetin, Celecoxib
Rationale: May increase risk of acute kidney injury and further decline of renal function

Medications: Estradiol/Levonorgestrel, Estradiol/Northindrone Acetate, Estradiol/ Drospirenone, Ospemifene, Estradiol/Norgestimate, Estrogen/Medroxyprogesterone, Estropipate, Estrogen, Estradiol, Doxazosin, Prazosin, Terazosin
Rationale: Lack of efficacy (oral estrogen) and aggravation of incontinence (alpha-1 blockers)

Medications: Disopyramide, Pyrilamine, Triprolidine,  Amitriptyline, Amoxapine, Clomipramine, Desipramine, Doxepin (>6 mg), Darifenacin, Imipramine, Fesoterodine, Nortriptyline, Flavoxate, Paroxetine, Oxybutynin, Protriptyline, Solifenacin, Trimipramine, Tolterodine, Trospium, Prochlorperazine, Promethazine, Benztropine, Trihexyphenidyl, Brompheniramine, Carbinoxamine, Chlorpromazine, Chlorpheniramine, Clozapine, Clemastine Loxapine, Cyproheptadine, Olanzapine, Dexbrompheniramine Perphenazine, Dexchlorpheniramine, Thioridazine, Dimenhydrinate, Trifluoperazine, Diphenhydramine (oral), Doxylamine, Hydroxyzine, Atropine (excludes ophthalmic), Meclizine, Belladonna alkaloids, Clidinium-chlordiazepoxide, Scopolamine (excludes ophthalmic), Dicyclomine, Homatropine (excludes ophthalmic), Hyoscyamine, Cyclobenzaprine, Methscopolamine, Orphenadrine, Propantheline
Recommendation: Avoid in men unless antimuscarinics are being used for urinary incontinence
Rationale: May decrease urinary flow and cause urinary retention
